bestBHT.bht: He adamantly refuses to count the impure person as his brother, demonstrating contempt towards his own flesh and blood. With bitter sarcasm, he addresses his father's reception of the prodigal son into superior favor, highlighting his resentment. The elder son's negative reaction mirrors the Pharisees' sin of disregarding their fellow men and opposes the father's forgiveness. The contrast between the elder son's refusal to accept his brother and the father's grace reveals a lack of understanding of God's mercy and the value of repentance.

Henry Alford: I will not count such an impure person my brother.
A covert reproach of his father for having given it to him.
Thou hast not only made him equal to me, but hast received him into superior favour.
Albert Barnes: This thy son - This son of 'thine.' This is an expression of great contempt.
Never was there a more striking instance of petty malice, or more unjustifiable disregard of a father's conduct and will.
It was true that the younger son had been guilty, and foolish, and ungrateful; but he was penitent, and 'that' was of more consequence to the father than all his property.
Marvin Vincent: This thy son. Not my brother, but with the bitterest sarcasm."
Was come [ηλθεν] . He says came, as of a stranger. Not returned.
Devoured [καταφαγων] . We say 'eat up;' the Greek said 'eat down' [κατα]'.
Philip Schaff: In expressing contempt of his brother the greatest sin against his father is uttered; so Pharisees sin most heinously against God in their feelings and acts towards their fellow-men.
It was preeminently Pharisaical to recall just then this fact.
In contrast with the latter part of Luke 15:29.
Archibald T. Robertson: This thy son (ο υιος σου ουτος). Contempt and sarcasm. He does not say: 'This my brother.'
Came (ηλθεν). He does not even say, came back or came home.
Devoured (καταφαγων). We say, 'eaten up,' but the Greek has, 'eaten down' (perfective use of κατα-).
John Gill: He will not own him in the relation of a brother, though the father had owned him in that of a son..." (Commentary)
The elder brother would have had another method taken with this younger son: he would have had him soundly whipped with the rod of the law..." (Commentary)

He thought such a conduct was unbecoming God, and his moral perfections; and what his brother was undeserving of; and opened a door to licentiousness; and highly reflected on his services, as of no value and regard." (Commentary)

bhtAttempts.bht: He refuses to acknowledge the impure person as his brother, covertly reproaching his father for showing favoritism towards the prodigal son. With bitter sarcasm, he belittles his brother as this thy son rather than my brother. The elder son's contemptuous attitude, expressing contempt towards his own flesh and blood, mirrors the Pharisees' sin of disregarding their fellow men. The contrast between the elder son's response and his father's forgiveness highlights the self-righteousness of the Pharisees, who would have punished the younger son harshly. The elder son's refusal to accept his brother and his disdain for his father's actions reveal a lack of understanding of God's grace and a failure to recognize the worth of repentance.

He adamantly refuses to count the impure person as his brother, demonstrating contempt towards his own flesh and blood. With bitter sarcasm, he addresses his father's reception of the prodigal son into superior favor, highlighting his resentment. The elder son's negative reaction mirrors the Pharisees' sin of disregarding their fellow men and opposes the father's forgiveness. The contrast between the elder son's refusal to accept his brother and the father's grace reveals a lack of understanding of God's mercy and the value of repentance.

He dismisses the impure person as his brother, using bitter sarcasm to express his disdain. The elder son's refusal to acknowledge his brother and his resentment towards his father's actions reveal a lack of understanding of the grace that should be extended. In his contemptuous attitude, the elder son mirrors the Pharisees' disregard for their fellow men. The stark contrast between the father's forgiveness and the elder son's unforgiving nature underscores the value of repentance and God's boundless mercy.

He arrogantly refuses to acknowledge the impure person as his brother, even going as far as making a covert reproach towards his father for showing favoritism. With bitter sarcasm, he belittles his brother, highlighting his resentment. The elder son's contemptuous attitude mirrors the sin of the Pharisees who disregard others. The stark contrast between the father's forgiveness and the elder son's unyielding nature reveals a misunderstanding of God's grace and the significance of repentance.

The elder son's negative reaction mirrors the Pharisees' sin of disregarding their fellow men and opposes the father's forgiveness. The contrast between the elder son's refusal to accept his brother and the father's grace reveals a lack of understanding of God's mercy and the value of repentance.
